["Orbital inclination - the tilt of a planet's orbit relative to its plane of reference, often related to another body like the Sun.", 'Parallax - the apparent shift in position of a nearby star (or other object) against the background of distant objects when viewed from different positions.', "Phase angle - the angle between an observer's line of sight and the light reflecting off an astronomical body, such as during lunar or planetary phases.", 'Ecliptic longitude - a celestial coordinate used to specify the eastward angular distance along the ecliptic from the vernal equinox point.', "Angle of elevation - when observing stars and planets, this is the angle between an object in the sky and the observer's local horizon.", 'Sextant measure - a historical navigational term referring to the angular distance measured using a sextant, often for determining latitude at sea by measuring angles of celestculed bodies above the horizon.', "Zenith angle - the angle between an object in the sky and the observer's zenith (the point directly overhead).", 'Solar declination - a solar astronomical term, which is the angle between the Sun at its path through the sky and the celestial equator.', 'Right ascension - one of the two coordinates used in the equatorial coordinate system to give the direction of an object in the sky as part of its position (the other being declination)', 'Celestial equator crossing - when a celestial body crosses the imaginary line in the sky directly above the Earth’s equator.', 'Evelyn Witts with her deep background in linguistics, etymology, and a penchant for semantics as they often relate to historical uses of language within astronomical contexts.']
